02 ‚Äî The Cricket Mafia
How SLC Became the Most Corrupt Board in World Cricket

The ICC's own anti-corruption chief stated that Sri Lanka has "more corruption investigations than anywhere else." A permanent ICC Anti-Corruption Unit office was established in Colombo ‚Äî the only country to receive this level of scrutiny.

The Patronage Machine

Sri Lanka Cricket doesn't function as a sports governing body ‚Äî it functions as a political patronage network. The SLC presidency is a stepping stone to political power and a distribution mechanism for TV rights money, sponsorship deals, and touring contracts. The current president, Shammi Silva, has held office since 2019 and was re-elected uncontested for his fourth term in March 2025. He simultaneously serves as Asian Cricket Council (ACC) President.

The mechanism is straightforward: SLC affiliates (cricket clubs) have voting rights in elections. These clubs are often paper entities controlled by politicians or business interests. By controlling enough clubs, a candidate can guarantee re-election without genuine competition. This is why Silva has been elected uncontested three times ‚Äî not because he's universally popular, but because the voting structure is captured.

The board is stacked with political loyalists rather than cricket experts. Public commentators have noted that "not a single renowned Sri Lankan cricketer is on the new board." Former cricketers who could reform the system "are reluctant to come forward due to corruption in this institution."
Critical Finding

The ICC Auditor General found serious irregularities in SLC's accounts between 2016 and 2022. Money from TV rights could not be traced. SLC issued statements about a $2 million transfer from its accounts, claiming "operational expenses," but no detailed accounting was provided.

The Sumathipala-Ranatunga War

The original power struggle that defined SLC's modern corruption era was between four-time president Thilanga Sumathipala and 1996 World Cup-winning captain Arjuna Ranatunga. Sumathipala accused Ranatunga and Aravinda de Silva of being "the first Sri Lankans to take bribes from bookies." Ranatunga countered by accusing Sumathipala of violating ICC regulations due to his family's connections to the gambling industry.

This war wasn't about cleaning up cricket ‚Äî it was about who controls the patronage. Both sides used cricket governance as a vehicle for political influence and financial gain. The lesson the system learned was that cricket boards are too valuable as political instruments to be reformed ‚Äî they must be captured.
The Self-Protecting System

The ICC's rules against government interference create a paradox: the one entity powerful enough to reform a corrupt board (the government) is prohibited from doing so. This means a captured board can perpetuate itself indefinitely, as long as it maintains formal compliance with ICC governance rules. The "mafia" doesn't just benefit from this rule ‚Äî it weaponises it. When the 2023 government tried to intervene, Silva immediately petitioned the courts and the ICC stepped in. The corrupt board was restored within days, using the very governance rules designed to protect cricket.

05 ‚Äî The Elitism Paradox
When Democratisation Killed the "Cricketing Brain"

The uncomfortable argument: Sri Lanka's golden era was produced by an elite school system that bred not just cricketers, but thinkers. The democratisation of cricket widened access but may have eroded the intellectual infrastructure that produced legends.
The Elite School Pipeline

Almost every Sri Lankan cricket legend came through the elite school system ‚Äî Royal College, Trinity College Kandy, St. Thomas' College, S. Thomas' Prep, Wesley, St. Peter's, St. Joseph's. The Royal-Thomian cricket match has been played annually since 1879 ‚Äî over 147 years uninterrupted, even during World War II.

These institutions didn't just teach cricket technique ‚Äî they embedded a culture of strategic thinking, pressure management, English-language fluency (critical for interacting with international cricket culture), and a gentleman's code. Kumar Sangakkara (Trinity), Mahela Jayawardene (Nalanda/elite Colombo), Arjuna Ranatunga (Ananda), Marvan Atapattu (Ananda) ‚Äî these weren't just talented batsmen. They were cricket intellectuals who could read a game five overs ahead.
What Was Lost

As cricket expanded beyond the elite schools to rural clubs and provincial systems ‚Äî an inherently positive development ‚Äî the infrastructure that cultivated "cricketing intelligence" was not replicated. Rural and non-elite school systems produce athletes, but without the coaching depth, competitive school cricket culture, and intellectual framework that the elite schools provided.

The result: Sri Lanka now produces explosive talent (Pathirana's death bowling, Hasaranga's wrist spin) but lacks the strategic captains, the calm accumulators, the players who can adjust a game plan mid-innings. The "cricketing brain" deficit isn't about intelligence ‚Äî it's about an institutional gap in how cricket thinking is taught and mentored.
The Murali Exception ‚Äî And What It Teaches

Muttiah Muralitharan came from a Tamil background outside the Sinhalese elite school system, yet became the greatest match-winner in cricket history. But Murali thrived because he was absorbed into an elite system (St. Anthony's Kandy) and then into a team led by elite-school captains (Ranatunga, then Jayawardene/Sangakkara) who knew how to utilise him strategically. The lesson: raw talent needs an intellectual framework around it to flourish. Today's Sri Lanka has the raw talent but not the framework ‚Äî neither from the old elite schools (whose influence has waned) nor from any new system that replaced it.
The Uncomfortable Truth

This isn't an argument for elitism per se ‚Äî it's an argument that when you dismantle an old system, you must build a new one. India managed this: the BCCI created sophisticated state-level academies (NCA in Bangalore), invested in coaching education, and used the IPL as a finishing school. Australia has the AIS and state-based cricket centres of excellence. England has the ECB pathway system.

Sri Lanka demolished the old elite pathway through democratisation (good) but built nothing comparable in its place (disastrous). The SLC was too busy enriching itself to invest in player development infrastructure. The result is a generation of cricketers with IPL-grade talent but club-level game management.

The #UnfollowCricketers Campaign

After Sri Lanka's 0-3 T20 drubbing by England, fans launched a coordinated social media campaign under the hashtag #unfollowcricketers. Thousands boycotted the Facebook pages of vice-captain Kusal Mendis and opener Dhanushka Gunathilaka ‚Äî himself the subject of a separate conduct investigation. The campaign wasn't just negative ‚Äî it was organised, sustained, and specifically targeted at individual players rather than the administration.

Kusal Mendis later spoke publicly about the abuse: "When we're doing badly is when we need the most support." But the culture of targeted personal attacks continued. Some fan posts even threatened violence, with warnings about "fans attacking cricketers' houses and burning cricketers' dummies like in India."
Why It's Uniquely Destructive

Sri Lanka is a small country (~22M people) where cricket is the dominant national sport. Unlike India, where 1.4 billion fans distribute their intensity across many players, or Australia, where multiple sports compete for attention ‚Äî in Sri Lanka, the pressure is concentrated on a tiny squad with nowhere to hide.

The player pool is small enough that fans know players personally ‚Äî their families, their schools, their neighbourhoods. Social media abuse isn't anonymous abstract criticism; it's your neighbour's son calling you a "Lonthaya" (loser/worthless person) on Facebook. Former captain Marvan Atapattu called for a complete social media ban for national cricketers in November 2025.
Practical Corrections
You can't force people to behave ‚Äî but you can change the information architecture:

1. Institutional Buffer: Create a dedicated SLC communications team that absorbs and redirects public anger toward governance reform rather than players. Use official channels to frame losses in analytical terms, not emotional ones.
2. Player Social Media Management: Professional social media managers for all national players (as IPL teams provide). Players should not manage their own accounts during tournaments.
3. Fan Education Campaigns: Partner with ICC's social media moderation program. Run campaigns showing how abuse affects performance ‚Äî make it about winning, not morality.

4. Redirect the Narrative: Create public "accountability dashboards" for the SLC board ‚Äî viewable stats on money spent, development programs, coaching hires. Give fans a productive target for their energy.
5. Legal Framework: Strengthen cyberbullying enforcement (only ~2,000 cases reported in 2024, half involving sexual harassment). Make credible threats to players actionable.

The venomous, hate-filled disparagement conveyed targeting the cricketers via social media is testament to the toxic nature of cricket fans in this country and the decay of our society in terms of values and attitudes.

The Captaincy Carousel

Charith Asalanka was removed as T20I captain in December 2025 after 18 months ‚Äî record: 10 wins, 11 losses, 2 ties. His batting collapsed under the weight of leadership: 156 runs in 12 innings at a strike rate of just 122 in 2025. Rather than developing captaincy skills over time, SLC's instinct was to replace him with Dasun Shanaka just before the World Cup ‚Äî a decision that created uncertainty rather than stability.

This pattern repeats across eras: captains are appointed, unsupported, blamed, and replaced. No captain since Angelo Mathews has been given genuine long-term backing with institutional support. The result is a squad where no one feels ownership of the team's direction.
Deep Issues

"Franchise vs. National Loyalty:" Players perform brilliantly in the IPL and LPL, where they have dedicated analysts, mental conditioning coaches, and clear roles. They return to the national setup, which offers none of this, and regress. The gap isn't talent ‚Äî it's support infrastructure.

Fitness & Conditioning: SLC's High Performance Centre has improved, but still lags behind the NCA (India) or AIS (Australia). Workload management between franchise and international cricket is poorly coordinated. Players arrive for national duty either over-bowled or under-prepared.

Mental Fragility: The 84/6 to 168/7 collapse against NZ isn't a technical failure ‚Äî it's a mental one. When pressure mounts, this team doesn't have the psychological resilience to adapt. This isn't innate ‚Äî it's a direct consequence of zero mental conditioning investment and a toxic external environment.

08 ‚Äî The NPP Paradox
Why the "Anti-Corruption" Government Can't Fix Cricket
The NPP (Anura Kumara Dissanayake) came to power on a wave of anti-corruption sentiment. They were vocal critics of the SLC system ‚Äî from opposition benches. In power, they've done nothing.
The Promise vs. Reality

Before taking office, the NPP was perhaps the most vocal critic of institutional corruption in Sri Lanka, including SLC. JVP/NPP parliamentarians raised SLC governance issues in parliament, demanded accountability for TV rights money, and called for structural reform. This was central to their populist anti-establishment appeal.

Since winning 159 seats (a supermajority) and forming government in 2024, the NPP's concrete cricket reform actions amount to: a budget review meeting in August 2025, the appointment of a Deputy Sports Minister (Sugath Thilakarathne), and a general instruction to "prepare a sports development plan." That's it.
Meanwhile, Shammi Silva was re-elected uncontested in March 2025 ‚Äî under the NPP's watch. The "anti-corruption" government stood by while the same board they called corrupt consolidated power.
Is it rhetorical capture?

The assessment that the NPP "used emotional rhetoric to attain power" is partially correct but incomplete. The NPP's inaction on cricket stems from three structural constraints: (1) the ICC suspension precedent of 2023 made any government directly aware that interference triggers international isolation, (2) the NPP's economic reform agenda consumes all political capital ‚Äî cricket reform yields no immediate economic return, and (3) the SLC "mafia" has legal protections that make reform litigation-heavy and politically costly. It's less cynical manipulation and more structural powerlessness masked by rhetorical boldness.
Why They Look Powerless

The ICC Trap: The 2023 suspension taught every Sri Lankan politician the same lesson: touch SLC, get suspended by ICC, lose cricket, face public backlash. The ICC's "no government interference" rule was designed to protect boards from authoritarian governments ‚Äî but in practice, it protects corrupt boards from democratic accountability.

Legal Fortification: SLC operates under a specific act of parliament (Sri Lanka Cricket Act) and its elections are conducted under defined rules. Changing these rules requires legislative action, which is slow, contested, and gives SLC time to mobilise legal challenges.

Political Prioritisation: The NPP inherited an economy in crisis ‚Äî IMF program compliance, debt restructuring, public service reform. Cricket reform is politically symbolic but economically irrelevant. With limited political capital, it gets deprioritised.

The Ironic Precedent: Former Sports Minister Mahindananda Aluthgamage was sentenced to 20 years in prison in May 2025 ‚Äî but for corruption unrelated to cricket reform. The NPP's anti-corruption drive is real but hasn't been directed at SLC specifically.

The Strategic Playbook: How a Savvy Politician Navigates This

The key insight is that the ICC prohibits government interference in board governance ‚Äî but it does not prohibit governments from changing the legal framework under which boards operate. This is the critical distinction.
Phase 1: Legislative Reform (Months 1-6)

Amend the Sri Lanka Cricket Act in parliament to mandate: (a) a provincial-based membership structure replacing the current club-based voting system, (b) mandatory inclusion of former international cricketers on the board, (c) independent financial auditing by a designated body, and (d) term limits for the presidency (max 2 terms). Frame this as "modernising the governance framework" ‚Äî not removing the board. The ICC has explicitly supported governance reform in other contexts (BCCI's Lodha Committee reforms were mandated by India's Supreme Court and the ICC did not intervene).
Phase 2: Provincial Cricket Boards (Months 6-18)

Establish 9 Provincial Cricket Associations (matching Sri Lanka's 9 provinces) as the new member bodies of SLC. Each PCA runs its own domestic competitions, academies, and coaching programs. These PCAs ‚Äî not captured cricket clubs ‚Äî elect the SLC president and board. This structurally dismantles the club-based patronage network.
Phase 3: ICC Engagement (Concurrent)

Before any legislative action, engage the ICC proactively. Present the reforms as "anti-corruption measures aligned with ICC governance best practices." Invite ICC governance advisors to consult on the legislation. Make the ICC a partner in reform rather than an adversary. The ICC's preference is always for good governance ‚Äî they suspended Sri Lanka reluctantly in 2023 and would welcome structural improvements.
Phase 4: Financial Transparency (Months 12-24)

Mandate that all SLC financial transactions above a threshold are published publicly. Create an independent Cricket Ombudsman with investigative powers. This doesn't "interfere" with cricket governance ‚Äî it creates accountability infrastructure.
The BCCI Precedent ‚Äî Why This Can Work

In 2016, India's Supreme Court appointed the Lodha Committee which mandated sweeping reforms to the BCCI: age limits, term limits, cooling-off periods, one-state-one-vote. The ICC did NOT suspend India, despite this being government (judicial) intervention. Why? Because the reforms were transparently aimed at better governance, not political capture. If Sri Lanka frames its reforms correctly ‚Äî and engages the ICC early ‚Äî the same logic applies. The ICC's real concern is governments installing puppet boards, not governments improving governance.

11 ‚Äî The Skills Gap & Analytics Deficit
Fielding, Patience, Game-Reading & The Data Desert
Sri Lanka recently hired India's former fielding coach R. Sridhar for a 10-day program. Australia has permanent analytics departments with real-time data. That gap tells the entire story.
üéØ Fielding

SLC hired R. Sridhar (India's former fielding coach) for a 10-day program in May 2025. India had Sridhar embedded for 7 years across 300+ international matches. The comparison: Sri Lanka gets a masterclass; India gets a system. SLC also hired Anton Roux as permanent fielding coach, but institutional depth remains lacking.
üìä Analytics

SLC's "Brain Centre" was recently relocated to the High Performance Centre in Colombo ‚Äî a positive step. But compare this to Australia's dedicated data science teams, England's CricViz partnership, or India's multi-million dollar analytics infrastructure. Sri Lanka is at least 5-7 years behind in data-driven decision-making for team selection, match strategy, and player development.
üïê Patience & Game Management

The collapse from 84/6 to 168/7 against NZ, and the inability to construct a chase of 169, reveal a fundamental game management deficit. T20 cricket rewards boldness but also requires situational awareness ‚Äî when to attack, when to rotate. Sri Lanka's batters either block or blast, with no intermediate gears. This is a coaching and mentoring gap, not a talent gap.
üîÑ Playing Spin

Ironic for a nation that produced Muralitharan: Rachin Ravindra's part-time left-arm spin took 4/27 to destroy Sri Lanka's batting. Playing spin requires footwork, reading variations, and shot selection under pressure ‚Äî skills that require specific practice against quality spinners. The domestic cricket system doesn't provide enough high-quality spin exposure because domestic pitches increasingly favour pace.
üß† Mental Conditioning

Perhaps the single biggest gap. Australia employs full-time sports psychologists embedded with every team. India's NCA has a dedicated mental conditioning program. Sri Lanka has no publicly known permanent sports psychology infrastructure for the national team. In a country where social media abuse is pervasive, this is an existential gap.
üìà Holistic Game Vision

The golden-era players could "see" a game as a unified whole ‚Äî batting, bowling, and fielding as interconnected strategies. Today's players are specialists in silos. This stems from T20-focused development where "one skill" is rewarded by franchise leagues. Correcting this requires deliberate multi-format exposure and coaching that teaches game scenarios, not just skills.

Sri Lanka is trapped in a dependency relationship where loyalty yields no protection and independence yields punishment.
13 ‚Äî The Calendar Crisis
The Slow Death of Sri Lankan Test Cricket

Sri Lanka played as few as 4 Tests in a recent year. Australia plays 12-15 annually. This isn't a scheduling quirk ‚Äî it's a structural dismantling of the format that builds the skills Sri Lanka most desperately needs.
The Calendar Squeeze

The ICC does not control the international cricket calendar the way FIFA controls football's calendar. It has "satisfied itself with carving out a slot for its annual events" while leaving bilateral scheduling to the boards. The result: the Big Three (India, England, Australia) play packed schedules of lucrative bilateral series against each other, while smaller nations scramble for whatever is left.

Sri Lanka's Test schedule has been steadily shrinking. In 2026, only 6 Tests are scheduled. For comparison, India and England regularly play 4-5 Test series against each other alone. The World Test Championship requires all Full Members to play each other at least twice over 10 years ‚Äî but "two" is the minimum, and for smaller boards, two is usually all they get.

The T20 World Cup and Champions Trophy now absorb 26% of the available calendar. Add the IPL window (April-June), other franchise leagues, and mandatory rest periods, and the space for bilateral Test cricket between smaller nations shrinks to almost nothing. South Africa ‚Äî who just became World Test Champions ‚Äî aren't scheduled to host a home Test until October 2026.
Why This Kills Sri Lanka Specifically

Test cricket builds the skills SL needs most. The patience, game management, spin bowling depth, batting technique, and strategic thinking that Sri Lanka's golden era was built on ‚Äî these are all Test cricket skills. Sangakkara, Jayawardene, and Muralitharan were forged in 5-day cricket. T20-first development produces explosive but brittle cricketers who can't construct an innings or bowl through a long spell.

1. The Jayasuriya Paradox

Sri Lanka's current head coach, Sanath Jayasuriya, was banned by the ICC in 2019 for refusing to cooperate with an anti-corruption investigation. He is now the head coach of the team the ICC's own anti-corruption unit monitors most closely. This isn't just ironic ‚Äî it sends a signal to players about the organisation's relationship with integrity. If the coach has unresolved corruption questions, how credible is the institutional message about playing clean? No mainstream analysis connects Jayasuriya's appointment to the ongoing corruption culture.
2. The Economic Crisis as a Cricketing Crisis

Sri Lanka's 2022 economic collapse didn't just affect fans emotionally ‚Äî it materially degraded cricket infrastructure. Ground maintenance budgets were cut. Domestic tournament funding dried up. Coaches left for better-paying positions abroad. The nutritional and fitness baselines for emerging players declined because training facility standards dropped. The economic crisis hollowed out the cricket system in ways that won't be visible for another 3-5 years as the affected generation reaches international level.
3. The Tamil & Muslim Talent Blackout

Sri Lanka's Northern and Eastern provinces ‚Äî majority Tamil and Muslim populations ‚Äî have been systematically underinvested in cricket development since the civil war ended in 2009. Despite 17 years of "peace," there is no meaningful provincial cricket infrastructure in Jaffna, Batticaloa, or Trincomalee. In a country of 22 million, excluding ~30% of the population from the talent pipeline is mathematically devastating. India draws from 1.4 billion across all regions; Sri Lanka effectively draws from 15 million in the Sinhalese south and west.
4. The "Assistant Coach" Brain Drain

Sri Lanka's best coaching minds ‚Äî the mid-level assistant coaches and analysts who actually develop players ‚Äî are being hired away by richer cricket boards and franchise leagues. Pakistan, Afghanistan, and even lower-ranked nations offer better salaries for coaching talent than SLC. This creates a paradox: Sri Lankan coaching expertise improves cricket everywhere in the world except Sri Lanka. The Brain Centre upgrade means nothing if you can't retain the brains.
5. The LPL as a Corruption Multiplier

The Lanka Premier League was meant to be SLC's IPL ‚Äî a revenue generator and development tool. Instead, it has become another vector for corruption. Praveen Jayawickrama was charged for failing to report fixing approaches during the LPL. The league has been postponed (2025 LPL was delayed), franchise owners have faced allegations of financial irregularities, and the competition has become a liability rather than an asset. Rather than developing talent, it has created more corruption exposure for young players.
6. The Geopolitics of Cricket Influence

Shammi Silva's dual role as SLC President and ACC President gives the Sri Lankan "mafia" regional influence that makes them harder to dislodge. Any ICC action against SLC now risks destabilising the ACC power structure. The corrupt leadership has effectively created a mutual protection pact at the regional governance level ‚Äî a sophisticated move that insulates them from reform pressure both domestically and internationally.
7. Cricket as Emotional Infrastructure in a Fragile State

During the 2022 economic crisis, Al Jazeera reported that cricket served as "mental healing" for Sri Lankans ‚Äî a unifying force in a country torn by racial, religious, and political divisions. When the cricket team fails, it doesn't just disappoint sports fans ‚Äî it removes one of the few remaining sources of collective positive national identity. The stakes of cricket reform in Sri Lanka are not merely sporting; they are psychosocial. A failing cricket team in a fragile post-crisis society amplifies hopelessness in ways that are difficult to quantify but real in their impact.
8. The IPL "Caste System" Within the Squad

The IPL auction creates an invisible hierarchy within the Sri Lankan squad that nobody discusses publicly. Players with IPL contracts (Hasaranga, Pathirana) carry financial security, international prestige, and confidence into the dressing room. Players who went unsold (Mendis, Nissanka, Asalanka, Shanaka, Wellalage) carry rejection and financial anxiety. This split isn't just psychological ‚Äî it affects team dynamics. IPL-contracted players have exposure to world-class analytics, coaching, and preparation; the unsold players return to SLC's comparatively primitive setup. The squad effectively operates at two different professional standards simultaneously, and the captain must manage both groups.
9. The BCCI's Soft Colonialism of Asian Cricket

Shammi Silva's dual role as SLC and ACC President appears to serve BCCI interests more than Sri Lankan ones. India's influence over the ACC means that Asian cricket's governance structures ‚Äî from tournament hosting to revenue distribution to Future Tour Programme scheduling ‚Äî are oriented around India's priorities. Sri Lanka's "alliance" with the BCCI has yielded co-hosting rights (on India's terms) but no meaningful structural benefits. This is what political scientists call "soft hegemony" ‚Äî the appearance of partnership masking an asymmetric power relationship where one party sets all the terms.
10. The Selection Committee as Political Instrument

Selection committees in SLC are not independent meritocratic bodies ‚Äî they are appointed by the SLC board and, by extension, aligned with the board's political interests. Player selection becomes a tool for rewarding loyalty, punishing dissent, and maintaining the patronage network. Players who speak out against SLC governance find themselves mysteriously "rested." Players aligned with the right power brokers get longer ropes. This is impossible to prove with direct evidence but is widely understood within the cricket community ‚Äî and it creates a culture of silence among players who know that their careers depend on not challenging the system.
